direction.raw_text: Muffled by the wet green forest. The very earth seems to tremble.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: DAY DISTANT GUN AND MORTAR FIRE

direction.raw_text: Darts out of a log, lifts itself on its hind legs and sniffs the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and SHOUTS, closer now, mix with the rumbling WAR SOUNDS in a veritable symphony of violence and confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lays splayed out, careless in death. A pair of SOLDIERS flash among the trees, running hunched over and low, and disappear into the gray blooms of SMOKE. For a moment the forest takes a breath. Nothing but trembling leaves. Then - The RATTLE of a Jeep Coming closer in fits and starts, GRINDING through low gears. A Willys MB appears, CRASHING through the undergrowth. It's driven by Private First Class KELLY ERNSWILER. Eighteen, if that. Not much meat on him. His insignias indicate he's in the 29th Infantry. His face might be attractive, under other conditions. He pauses and pulls a map from the pocket of his M41 standard- issue field jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To give himself courage, he SINGS Tommy Dorsey's "I'll Be Seeing You [in all the old familiar places]" while maneuvering the Jeep through the bushes and rocks. He drives straight for a fallen LOG, GUNS the engine and tries to go over it. The Jeep's FRONT WHEELS catch on the log. The BACK TIRES spin. Kelly gets out. Takes off his M1 combat helmet and wipes his face. Assesses the situation. He grabs a BRANCH. Jams it under the wheel, trying to lever the Jeep free. When -- The STUTTER of a nearby MACHINE GUN startles him. The branch SNAPS against Kelly's weight. He slips and falls in the mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Determined, he grabs his pack and carbine and sets off on foot through the forest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where the hell are those Krauts?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly strides purposefully out of the woods. Pauses against a split-rail fence beneath the innocent sun. Across the clearing stands a seemingly abandoned BARN. But not for long, as TWO GERMAN INFANTRYMEN appear around the corner of it. Kelly moves behind a tree to assess the situation. Unaware, the Germans smoke and talk. Kelly's too far away to hear them but he watches their every move. They're relaxed, not as on guard as they should be. Their Karabiners rest slung across their backs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bingo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly focuses himself. Then he shoulders his carbine. Pulls out his dog tags and kisses them grimly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes his Smith & Wesson 1917 PISTOL from his pistol belt and steps out into the SUNLIGHT FIELD in plain sight of the guards. Surely he knows they can see him. He must want them to see him. But they don't. Too busy passing nudie wallet photos. Halfway across the open grass, Kelly raises the pistol but does not aim it. Just strides steadily closer, arms spread out, making himself an easy target. Crazy as it seems, Private Kelly Ernswiler is trying to get himself killed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "And so they buried Hector, breaker of horses."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly pauses not twenty feet from the Germans, FIRES into the air and waves -- -- when from behind him comes a voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly whips around to face a third German, the OFFICER. His pistol points right into the Officer's shocked pink young face. Point blank range. Only - Kelly doesn't fire. He just lowers the pistol. The German smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Infantrymen have recovered from their idle and come running. One of them yanks Kelly's hands behind his back and pushes him into the barn roughly. Kelly doesn't struggle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Eine maus findet den kase.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kill me Adolf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mien Prisoner!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Siegfreid and Roy. What are you waiting for? Kill me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly sits slumped in a chair, legs tied up. One of the Germans shines a flashlight in his face. Kelly squints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Officer produces a piece of paper and a fountain pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly takes the pen and examines it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer pokes the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly thinks about it for a minute - should he or shouldn't he - but sighs and begins writing. After a few lines, the Officer snatches the paper away and passes it to an Infantryman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer wheels around and scowls at the speaker. He seems to be getting a bit hysterical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Kelly glare at each other. The Officer FIRES his Luger into the rafters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer grabs his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly laughs. The officer slaps him. Kelly jerks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly another AMERICAN GI appears behind the German in the shadows. Only Kelly can see him. The GI motions to Kelly "keep talking" while he gets into a better position with his M-1 rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The GI shoots the two infantrymen who fall in exaggerated pain and commence death throes. Quick as a flash, the GI's Colt 1911 PISTOL is at the German Officer's neck, his M-1 in his other hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The GI's eyes widen. He looks at Kelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the GI does anyway. The Officer SHRIEKS, grabs at his neck, and falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The GI holds out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly takes the hand of the grinning all-American type guy. About his own age, but BART takes up more space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer gets up and dusts off his uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Officer grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart helps him up and checks his regulation-issue Timex.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The German Officer crosses his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly gets up from the chair and falls over. His legs are still tied.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on you pussies. Let's get this over with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (German accent) You will write your mother. Tell her how you will die now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Genuine Third Reich issue, no less. Nice work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will write. How you die alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mother and I don't have that kind of relationship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hisses) Write.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough. Now you will beg for your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What don't you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupts sheepishly in German accent) The protocol says we should -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the fucking protocol. (to Kelly) Beg!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beg - for - your - life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got to be kidding me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Silence. Now I have a little fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's against the rules.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sneers) There are no rules in war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Officer) You've never killed anyone before, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I shower in the blood of my victims --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No wonder you smell so bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't shoot, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you look at the manners on this guy? (to German) Remember to thank me when I kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really, not in the neck -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) You all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. My elaborate death scene wasn't going anywhere anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to give you a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's okay. They'll get me eventually. If you can't get killed in a war, when can you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Look on the bright side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bart. Bart Bowland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly. Kelly Ernswiler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mimics) Bart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean - that's Irish, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from the floor, now with a decidedly American accent) Wow man, this is a really beautiful scene and all, but I have to interrupt. (to Bart) Why the fuck did you have to shoot that cap so close to my neck? You gave me a powder burn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen you wienerschnitzel. You should talk. You slapped me. I'm not your bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what was that whole creepy death wish thing about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well it didn't work, now did it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) Sometimes I get so caught up in the moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what was that ridiculous shit about making me write to my mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Inspired, wasn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dude, you made him write to his mother? Who are you, Dr. Phil?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (also with American accent) Can we get up now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Might as well. There's only an hour left anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) Admit it. You were scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snorts) Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The DEAD GI gets up and walks off with the GERMANS and some other SOLDIERS, done for the day. Bart and Kelly walk back to the stranded Jeep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart unfolds an entrenching tool from his belt and digs under the back wheels, building up dirt. Then he goes around to the front and puts his shoulder against the hood. Bart rocks the Jeep while Kelly pumps the gas. The Jeep finally pulls free and SPRAYS Bart with mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks over his shoulder and starts backing away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart stands there, dripping with mud, shocked. About a hundred feet away Kelly stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart walks towards the Jeep. Kelly backs it up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart climbs in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That Willys yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup. Just got her. Three summers packing out at Shop Rite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My bad. Thanks though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't resist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Real funny, Ernswiler. You might still get your chance to die today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The customers are all REENACTORS. Some Yanks, some Germans, a few Scottish and North African irregulars. "Boogie-Woogie Bugle Boy" plays on the jukebox. Bart and Kelly sit in a booth together. Bart has an easy, confident manner and expansive gestures. Kelly eats hunched over, like someone might try and steal his food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both eat for a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Kelly looks at Bart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart throws his napkin on his plate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Character building? Those crazy guys from Ann Arbor tied them to a dock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) That's what you get for invading Wisconsin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: D-Day at Kenosha was nothing. At Guadalcanal Chillicothe there was a guy who actually injected himself with malaria.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you live, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shaker Heights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That explains the death wish. Me too. What street?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Penn Place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chewing) Hmm, don't know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not technically in Shaker Heights - but I go to Shaker Heights High.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Langely Prep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I got kicked out of Shaker Heights High because my birdhouse came unglued in honors woodshop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. I would have gone to Langely myself only my polo pony had the fits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No matter. (raises his voice to address the room) We're all soldiers here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right./Here, here./ Whooping, cheers, etc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly pulls up into the circular gravel drive. Bart's house is fancy. A nice yard and a pool. Bart hops out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly watches Bart go into his house and smiles in spite of himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You should come over some time. Service our lawnmower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would, but then I might soil my croquet whites. You understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How bourgeois. Cheerio then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly's house is a also pretty nice, nothing to be ashamed of. It is smaller and weirder. The flowers and bushes are overgrown and strange sculptures dot the yard, some leaning at precarious angles. Kelly washes his Jeep in the driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly buffs the headlamps with a chamois. The Jeep looks good as new. He pulls a canvas cover over it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sleep tight Hot Lips.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly walks in on his dad ABE making sandwiches. A great big pile of cheese and PB&J.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly doesn't smile at this. He looks at the sandwiches and puts his finger to his chin in a gesture so facetious it's downright angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abe grabs two pieces of bread from a loaf. He looks kind. A bit ill-used by life. The phrase "rode hard and put away wet" comes to mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finishes that sandwich and adds it to the pile. Kelly pauses while opening the refrigerator. His back tightens. He slams the door with his foot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abe pauses over a slice of bread only briefly. The hostility is nothing new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly walks through the kitchen and out the back door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sergeant Keller! How was the war? Did we win?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me guess. Happy Meals for the wavy gravy wellness center?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As usual, your cynicism is refreshing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As usual, your cheerful optimism makes me ill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lightly) You should get that checked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Sure thing, doc. Say hello to Leif Garrett for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly opens the screen door and pokes his head in. A family of Chinese immigrants, the Lings, paints canvases at long worktables. There's a MOTHER, father MAO, grandmother XIOU-XIOU, SON and DAUGHTER. Finished canvases hang from the walls and lean in piles against it. All of them are portraits of animals. Some have on hats or clothes. Kelly's mom EVE shows grandmother XIOU-XIOU a few strokes with a paintbrush. Eve wears jeans. She's one of those young-looking mothers Kelly's friends would have crushes on. If he had any friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve demonstrates on the painting - a pair of monkeys in French court dress. Kelly looks over his mom's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandmother Xiou-Xiou dabs at the painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve moves along the row, stopping to look at the paintings in progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Eve has stopped behind Mao's painting. She's not paying attention to Kelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures at the image of a horse done Santa Fe style, lots of pastels, very abstract. Mao looks at her quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His family nods in support of this rash aesthetic statement. Eve rolls her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly breaks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve moves down the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this the family nods and smiles to each other, pleased with the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve looks up at him for the first time. Takes in his filthy uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve stops at Mother Ling's painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother Ling looks up at Kelly, who's scowling. She smiles and nods, understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly leaves. Eve's busy talking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) Son of Eve. You are very dirty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (awkward) A rough charge. You know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) Don't touch anything. We have to get ready for the Starving Artist show. (to Xiou-Xiou) Now Nana, the gold has to be feathery, not gloppy - see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) She loves the gold. Always overuses it. And usually her touch is so light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gold is the color of the sun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know why we never have anything to eat in this house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mao, what did we say about the eyes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More - empathy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. And didn't I tell you to put in more cacti?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) No, no more cacti. Too busy. Simplicity is best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh boy. I'm not having this battle with you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because your husband takes food from his own family to feed every loser druggie in Cleveland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you can always chip in here. We're ordering pizza later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Some people have to work later. (casual) Will you drop something off at the dry cleaners for me tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sweetie, you know what we said about paying for the war things. Nothing's changed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the only thing I ever ask you for -- EVE Don't be dramatic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's important to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're just going to have to find a way to pay for it yourself then, I guess. (to Mother Ling) No - not that way - the sky should be stormier. Angry clouds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do I bother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More brown, less blue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly comes back in a grabs a sandwich off the pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at him and bites into the sandwich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly leaves with the sandwich. Abe sighs and picks up more bread.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now Keller, who needs that sandwich more - you or the daughter of a crack addict trying to make a new life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about the son of a heroin addict trying to get ready for work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That went well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On the walls a poster for the Civil War miniseries next to one of Led Zeppelin. Some maps. A globe. Models of fighter planes and a set of old tin soldiers. Oh yeah, and his mom's ORIGINAL PAINTING, the one that started it all, this one signed by her - a very intense looking pink rabbit glaring out of the canvas with huge eyes. He sits on the edge of the bed for a minute staring into space before he peels off his muddy uniform piece by piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, the graveyard shift. Musak Steely Dan. Kelly unpacks cat food. Thousands and thousands of little cans of it. It's hard to keep the rows straight on the shelves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the night cashier, stands at her register. She's plain- looking now but she'll be beautiful later when she figures out who she is. Not another soul in the store. Sarah wanders over to Kelly's aisle as if pulled by a magnet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly doesn't stop working. He's got a system.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly grabs another handful of cans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly pauses. He puts two cans on the shelf very deliberately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at her, thinks about this, and stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah covers her head, huddled behind the boxes of cat food, dodging cans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly goes back to stocking, satisfied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah stands up and starts to wander away but Kelly makes a peace offering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah looks at her feet, considering whether or not to accept it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So how'd your battle go today? I still don't understand how you could reenact the Battle of the Bulge in seventy-two degree weather. (plays with hair) Didn't all those guys freeze to death?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, a Port-a-John fell over on a couple of guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's gross.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: War is hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why do you do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're never more alive then when facing simulated death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Maybe I should try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are William J. Stone of the 1st Airborne, pinned down in Noville. The Germans have the high ground and they're shelling your position heavily. (starts throwing cans) You're holed up in a stone barn. Sustaining heavy casualties. Running low on ammo. The cries of wounded men fill the air like the cries of hungry babies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your commanding officer gets hit in the face, dies. At 1 p.m. you lose radio contact with headquarters. If you withdraw, the Germans will flank the entire Allied forces arrayed along Bastogne and break the front. What do you do? What do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Battle of Bulge, the Southern Shoulder, December '44.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I asked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. Want a snack? We got a whole shipment in of busted Oreo's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll accidentally drop a couple pints of milk and meet you over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sarah and Kelly sit on milk crates, pass the cookies back and forth and get philosophical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fishes for a cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An ANGRY WOMAN pushes open the swinging door of the backroom with her loaded shopping cart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah gets up. Kelly stays right where he is, finishing a cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sarah smiles and hurries away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The frozen food woman came in with her kids. They must eat out of those little cardboard trays every night. One of the kids looked like cardboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know we stock more flavors of cat food than we do baby food?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sixteen flavors of baby food including the toddler meals-in-ajar, thirty- one flavors of cat food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next time you should tell that woman to buy her kid some cat food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this store open? I've been waiting up front. If the store's closed, it shouldn't have a sign that says twenty- four hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a lot of coupons and I don't want to be here when they expire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Sarah) Charge her double for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly walks down the hall with his army-issue BACKPACK slung over one shoulder. Besides a serious case of bedhead, he looks normal. No one says hi to him as he makes his way to his locker. As he twirls the combination and opens it, he notices LANCE -- short and wide, built like a tank, prematurely balding, and his girlfriend BRIDGET embracing a few lockers down. They kiss raunchily, their tongues darting in and out of each other's mouths. Lance sees Kelly looking and stops kissing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly shakes his head and gets a book out of his locker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly closes his locker and walks away. Bridget wipes her mouth guiltily. Lance shakes his head and pulls Bridget to him, grinding his pelvis against hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck are you looking at, GI Jane?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No really, what makes you think you can look at me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I honestly didn't know it was you. I thought it was a free preview of the Spice Channel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's pretty funny. You got dental insurance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLASSROOM -- DAY The lights are off in history class. The teacher MR. NORMAN shows slides on the Civil War. The more we see the clearer it becomes that they are his own photos from a vacation spent visiting the memorials. Mr. Norman smiles out at his class in shot after shot. He clicks the remote and a photo of his WIFE, crouched over and wearing shorts, drinking from a garden hose appears on screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurries through to the next slide. It doesn't matter anyway. Everyone is almost asleep. Except Kelly, who becomes increasingly irritated the more Mr. Norman talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly shifts in his seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Mr. Norman doesn't start talking again. He waits, looking at Kelly, smiling blandly. Until the silence becomes uncomfortable. And Kelly gets mad.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . NORMAN Whoops!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORMAN And here, at Gettysburg, the ranks of Union soldiers fought bravely on. They were willing to give their lives so that others might be free.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NORMAN Is there a problem Mr. Ernswiler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. Isn't this analysis a tad simplistic? I mean, maybe for a second grade history class, sure - but to insist on still characterizing the Civil War as some moral struggle? The soldiers were drafted - the only ones who had to fight were the ones who couldn't afford to pay their way out. (losing it) Why don't you talk about the Draft Riots? Where are your slides for that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Fresh flowers and a crocheted tissue box hoodie make the place cozy. Kelly sits across the desk from PRINCIPAL HOLMSTEAD, a well- groomed woman with a gentle talk show host demeanor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly doesn't move. He's not into this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ms. Holmstead is exasperated, but she likes him in spite of herself. He's a smart cookie. She's got to change her strategy. She leans back in her chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her chair SQUEAKS as she leans forward and looks at Kelly intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holmstead tries again. She looks down at his file.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly shrugs. Holmstead searches his face for any clues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head and swings her chair towards the window and gazes out at the front walkway of the school. Her face clears. Something's clicked.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What gives you the idea that you can or ought to question the curriculum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or question your teacher?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. I mean, who ever heard of a classroom dialog? Not Socrates.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly, you're a very bright boy. But you're making some serious mistakes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't need to. Everyone else makes them for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This anger must be masking a lot of hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was wondering what the tissues were for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see you're not going to college next year. What are your plans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do I get through to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Advertisers use status and sex to appeal to my demographic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think we can come up with a punishment which might actually be more of an opportunity for you to realize your true potential.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: School's been out for a while. The first rush had already left. Kelly comes down the front steps and starts across the parking lot to his Jeep. Lance steps out from behind an SUV and intercepts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly hardly stops walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lance runs and grabs Kelly's backpack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly tries to start walking again but Lance has hold of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lance grabs Kelly's arm and yanks it back. Kelly still seems unconcerned. Suddenly he pulls away, but Lance keeps hold of his backpack. Lance holds the backpack up next to his head and points at it, gleeful. Lance walks away towards his car. Kelly runs after him. Lance holds Kelly off easily with one hand and throws the backpack into his SUV. They STRUGGLE for a minute, until Lance pushes Kelly away, gets in the car. Kelly runs next to the car and pounds on the window as Lance drives off. Finally, Kelly gives up. Lance turns out of the parking lot and HONKS the horn. Kelly shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You upset Bridget.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You need to apologize.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do, make out with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you fucking with me? You little fucker. Want to play, fuckface?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just used fuck as a verb, noun, and adjective. Impressive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's see what Beetle Bailey's got in his knapsack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rim job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly sifts through a pile of backpacks looking for a replacement. From his post behind the counter, Bart sees him and comes over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly. Hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You work here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a couple days a month, to get a heads-up on the latest stuff. What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looking for a backpack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that all? Don't bother. I have a couple extras at home. I could give you one if you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Sure, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly stands a bit awkwardly waiting for Bart to get the key from the desk to open the door in the corner. The door finally swings open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart and Kelly stand between shelves piled high with war memorabilia. Uniforms in vacu-pac sealed bags, weapons in shoeboxes, cannonballs and tattered and gunsmoke-darkened flags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly holds up a flask in a leather case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart opens the long box. Nestled inside is a leg bone with a foot attached to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly nods. That is balls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart puts down the box carelessly and paws through the piles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Very impressive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dad's real into hoarding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grant's field flask.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow. Your dad should meet my history teacher. He sent me to the principal's office today for questioning his G- rated interpretation of the Civil War.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would, but now the principal's making me give a speech on the Civil War at an assembly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing in sympathy and amusement) What is he, some kind of sadist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She thinks she's doing me a favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, she must think you're really screwed up. Are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends on who you ask. Everyone's got an opinion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabs box) Take this. That'll shut them up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stonewall Jackson's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you imagine that? Losing your leg and getting back up on your horse? Unbelievable. What balls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's got so much crap crammed in here he doesn't even notice when it's missing. I saw a backpack in here somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bart and Kelly sit at the kitchen table drinking sodas, waiting for MINNIE, the housekeeper, to finish making them dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause. Kelly decides to tell him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought he had a couple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd feel weird taking one out of the tomb of Tutenkamen anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trust me, you shouldn't. (burps) Where'd your old one go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I lost it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone took it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You let someone take it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't let him. I told off some idiot -- BART Sounds like your mouth gets you into trouble a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm telling you, it's not me, it's the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bart's older sister comes in. She's older. Definitely in college, if not out. And totally shockingly beautiful. Otherworldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly laughs. And looks at Tabby more closely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens the fridge and gets a yogurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby leaves. Kelly's distracted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart rolls his eyes, indicating what he thinks of good old Miner. Kelly nods, doesn't say anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly glances at the door Tabby left from.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at Bart with suspicion -- and respect.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tabby, this is Kelly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) Don't give him any money, whatever you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All these little old ladies are looking for him in Arizona. He took their retirement money and bought defective bazookas with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very funny. We're paying attention to you, are you happy now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finally, my life is complete. Fait accompli.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Tabby) Minnie's making sloppy joes. Want one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sloppy joe? Sloppy no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to go take a shower. Will you call me when Miner gets here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's Miner?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fiance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I'm going to the flea market on Saturday. I have a line on a couple dealers. You could get a backpack there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah? Flea market, land of bargains.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Especially if you know who to talk to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly hops out of his Jeep and walks towards the front of the school. Lance is there, hanging out with Bridget and some of his Cro- Magnon FRIENDS. He wears a WW II CAP, overseas airborne style, obviously Kelly's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cro-Magnons grunt approvingly at this witty repartee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ooh. The Cro-Magnons laugh at Lance and EGG him on - "You gonna take that?"/"He just called you a fag", etc. Lance frowns and grabs Kelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still holding on to him with one arm, he SLAPS Kelly hard across the face with the other. Kelly's knees give a bit. Lance holds him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lance looks over at her and releases Kelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly is hurt but covering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly frowns and adjusts his clothes. Tries to re-wet the dry inside of his mouth with his tongue. He turns slowly and trudges up the stairs. Sarah has been watching the whole thing from the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey fuckface. Like my new hat? I just joined the Boy Scouts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you stay in it long enough, maybe you'll get your fudgepacker badge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a regular Howie Mandel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay babe. (to Kelly) One day you and me will be alone. And won't that be nice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad my mom won't let me date yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you mess with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right. I should give him a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly watches TV in the living room. His cheek has a nice bruise on it. Eve enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve goes to her purse and rifles through it to find her wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly jabs at the remote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve waits through this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve comes over to Kelly. He sighs and puts his hand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her hand up but he moves away from it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Kelly, you're home. Good. I need you to go to the art supply store for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get Abe to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was going to but he had to go lead a meeting at Care House.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a surprise. EVE I'll make it up to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where have I heard that before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When are you going to give me a break?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me think - maybe when I finally forget every single word of The Little Mermaid soundtrack I'd listen to in the car waiting for him to score. No, probably when I don't prepare myself before I go into the bathroom, expecting to find him passed out on the floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, you know what? I know I'll be able to put it all behind me when I go away to college. (slaps his forehead, pretend remembering) Only, I can't go because someone spent my college fund on Mexican Black Tar. So looks like I'll have to try to forget at Shop Rite, where I'll be working for the rest of my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right. You have every reason to crawl into the corner and give up. But please just get me some paints first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We need burnt sienna, cadmium red, and midnight blue. Two tubes of blue. (looks at him) What happened to your face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks through the paints, picking out tubes. He looks up and sees Tabby browsing the paintbrushes. He's suddenly nervous. He knocks over a few cans of thinner. Almost leaves. Instead, he gathers his courage, goes to the display opposite hers and waits to catch her eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It takes Tabby a second to recognize him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby looks at him suspiciously like she's not sure whether to believe him. Tabby finishes with the mediums and moves onto the paints. Kelly follows her, staying in the opposite aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In spite of herself, Tabby laughs at this. This gives Kelly more confidence. He leans over the aisle to see what she's looking at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly comes around and leans nonchalantly against the shelves, knocks more things over and fumbles to replace them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby walks to the counter with her brushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks down and partially confesses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby signs the slip and takes the bag. She walks out, Kelly with her, matches her pace, talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby gets into her car. Kelly leans into her window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby tries to conceal her smile and starts her car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She drives away. Kelly stands there watching. Then he winces.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're having a sale on glitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hello. What happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) Tennis injury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You paint?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you see... That's a difficult question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't really feel comfortable calling anything done since the Renaissance "painting." We might have a more experimental interaction with the picture plane, but our skills have suffered from it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're working with acrylic. Why? Oil's much - richer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh you're not one of those oil snobs are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just - isn't acrylic a bit - jejune?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jejune? You're jejune. How old are you anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Older than my years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you paint?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you know, my mother's kind of an artist, so -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That explains it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That explains nothing. Doesn't anyone believe in innate knowledge anymore? Michelangelo was fifteen when he painted the Infanta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Infantas are Spanish. Michelangelo was Italian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly. One world, one people. Just like Jesse Jackson envisioned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well - Kelly. Nice talking to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell did you just say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly pulls up in his Jeep. He turns off the engine but doesn't get out. Just sits there. He doesn't want to go in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colored plastic flags droop in the sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart sweeps his eye over everything. A SKINNY GUY wearing a wife beater has some not half-bad stuff. Kelly, bruise faded to yellow and green, examines a glass mason jar of what seems to be dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart acts casual, hands clasped behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart pulls out a paper bag and offers it to the skinny guy, who looks inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly is shocked. The skinny guy looks at his suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The skinny guy looks at Bart, and in the bag again. He goes to get the backpack. Kelly's impressed by this smooth exchange.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) That there's actual sand from Iwo Jima.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or your sister's sandbox.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it don't come with no certificate of authenticity. (considers) I could write one up for you, I suppose. Get it notarized.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that's quite all right. Actually, I'm in the market for medals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. I got a couple purple hearts. A Silver Star. DSC. Can't sell them to you though. They were gramp's. (wink)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They have a lot of sentimental value -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General Ulysses S. Grant's field flask, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Throw in one of those backpacks and we'll call it even.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BETWEEN ROWS Kelly and Bart weave through the maze of stands. Kelly now holds the backpack.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Buying and selling US service medals is illegal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly. That's why the resale value is so high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what they teach you at Langely?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be so naive. We all have our skeletons. Some of them just pay more than others.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm not even going to ask about the flask.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't ask, don't tell. The army gets everything right, don't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A frowsy WOMAN in a muumuu sits fanning herself in front of an extensive display of pins and buttons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman considers this, her fan working back and forth lazily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart paws through the box. Acts casual.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You boys look like Goldwater fans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never been accused of that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well jeez, you don't have to be insulted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything military?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fish around in that cigar box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want for the box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifteen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be so hasty. (fanning) I got a few Geraldine Ferraro pins I'm looking to unload.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly and Bart, now wearing the smiling black & white face of Geraldine Ferraro, eat disgusting yet delicious flea market food and watch a slow-motion bingo game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They eat for a minute to the soothing sounds of the BINGO CALLER: TWENTY-ONE, THIRTEEN, FOUR, SEVENTY-EIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart does some fake sign language to help Kelly out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart pushes Kelly, who grabs his arm like it got hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Interested, Bart leans forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goldwater fan. I think that's some kind of insult.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at Dartmouth. Where are you going to go to school?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, you have that luxury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) I didn't have much say in the matter. Everything has been decided for me since birth. I'm not whining about it. Play the hand you're dealt, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy for you to say. You got a royal flush.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you crazy? My life sucks. Everyone's always telling me what to do. You can't fight it. Go with the flow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Tabby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She got to go where she wanted. Sarah Lawrence. Six years. She's almost done with grad school. Yale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't think people actually went to Yale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking) I don't know. I mean, she drives off in her car in September. For all we know, she could just pull her car over in Albany and sleep there until May.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a joke. Joke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Is that what one of those sounds like? Somehow, I always imagined they would be funnier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sarah Lawrence? Isn't that for lesbians?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to your face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember the backpack incident?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one with mad cow-diseased hamburger meat for brains? That would be the one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to lower myself to his level.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not. But there are alternatives...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alternatives?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't you ever heard of the 193rd Special Operations Wing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well do you want to get this guy or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Let's get the fuck out of here, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the move) I have some things to show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bart and Kelly sit amidst a spread of books, papers, and electronic equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart opens a pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart grabs a book and starts flipping through pages. Tabby enters with an armful of art supplies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart doesn't look up. He grabs another book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know what this is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eighteen volts of pure freedom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds dangerous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it is. Unless you know how to handle it.

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on tight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close call.

dialogue.raw_text: Have you been drinking?

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks in at his parents, checking to make sure they're still asleep. When he leaves ABE opens his eyes and listens to the door CLOSE downstairs.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly stands awkwardly on the front stoop with his backpack. Minnie opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly? Bart's not here, he -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's all right. Actually, I'm here to see Tabby. Just to do a little painting with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's out back in her studio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tabby stands barefoot in the sunlight, a palette knife in her hand. Music's playing. Jeff Buckley. She looks over as the door opens, surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes back to painting. Kelly stands there for a minute, waiting for her to say something else, give him an invitation. She doesn't. Until she looks up and sees him standing in the same place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks through them and picks one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes off his backpack and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly busies himself pulling out paints and other supplies. He can't help but look at her. The light hits her hair and she glows. She catches him looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns back to her painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly sets up his canvas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly feels the tubes of paint. Nervous. Squirts some color out. Looks over his shoulder at her. He's trying to get his act together, to be cool about being there, in the studio, alone with her. Trying to figure out how to play it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miner opens the door. See Kelly. Smiles like the stockbroker he is and crosses to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miner holds out his hand for a good old-fashioned shake. Kelly takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miner looks confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly smiles eagerly at Miner over the edge of his canvas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly spreads his arms out and flaps them a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miner stares at Kelly. He can't tell what he might be making fun of, or if it might be him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly rolls his eyes at this uninspired response, though Miner doesn't see it. He grabs Tabby's paintbrush and pulls her to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly smiles his most idiotic energetic smile and slaps paint on his canvas in exaggerated strokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby kisses Miner. He realizes there's no convincing her and sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miner looks at Kelly, who looks away. Then he puts his hands in his pockets and leaves. Tabby and Kelly paint in silence for a while. Kelly moves around to look at his canvas from different angles, like he's copying what he thinks a painter would do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby stops and puts down her brush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly paints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly is suddenly very involved with his painting. He has a hard time making eye contact with Tabby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks up her brush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at her seriously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awkward silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly stops and sighs, now back in serious artist mode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tabby stops painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly puts up his thumb in an approximation of an artist's gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly stops squeezing paint onto his palette. His gestures slow down. He's taking this in. Then he shakes it off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kelly?

dialogue.raw_text: Quite all right. (smiles as an afterthought) So, what do we have here, a little painting class?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? What's your real job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be stock boy at the Shop Rite. But, as President Don Kaminsky says, every employee is part owner. So you could say I'm a captain-of- industry in training. Kind of capitalist larva.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's quite an image.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only if you see the most magical part. Do you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One day I'll be a beautiful butterfly. First I'll have to be a pupa though. I figure I won't be going out much then. Pupa: the awkward adolescence of the insect world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever it takes to get you through the day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have the afternoon off. Come away with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not at a good stopping point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, come on. They'll still be here. (to Kelly) I know you'll still be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really shouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But everyone will be coming soon. And it will get all crazy, and we won't have any time to ourselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will. I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like tonight? We can practice honeymoon suite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe. Probably.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he always like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Overbearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just because he didn't want to picture you as a pupa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, he will - later. When he's alone. Whether he wants to or not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that though. How he wanted you to stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to be with me. What's so bad about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just because some one wants to be with you doesn't mean they're good for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one should ever ask you to stop. If you stop, you might not be able to start again. Or you might start again, only things will be different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's sweet -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not sweet, actually. It's just the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I can take care of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When's the wedding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the end of the month. But don't ask me about it. It makes me nervous.

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Is something wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you painting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really, there are so many layers of - imagistic symbolism - that I really don't feel comfortable summing it up, but, well - it's a recurring dream image. A mermaid riding a rocket ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, "how?" Sidesaddle. She's riding it sidesaddle. She's got a fish tail, for chrissake. I haven't decided yet if she's got scuba gear on or not.

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have any idea what you're talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, some people actually say what they really think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if they don't know what they really think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't matter. It's called being yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds boring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not boring. Scary and wonderful and exciting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. I'm trying to create here. Stop distracting me.

direction.raw_text: This annoys Kelly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart glances at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart shakes his head.

direction.raw_text: Kelly's video game character dies. He drops the controller.

direction.raw_text: Bart plays on. He's keeping a lid on everything while Kelly gets more and more agitated.

direction.raw_text: Kelly looks at Bart in disbelief.

direction.raw_text: Bart won't meet his eyes.

direction.raw_text: Kelly gets up and grabs his jacket.

direction.raw_text: . OLD SOLDIERS' HOME - DAY A few OLD SOLDIERS sit sunning in chairs in the industrial feeling living-room. Bart and Kelly sit across from CHARLIE HAYES, an old black guy, playing dominos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie sorts his tiles and scowls. He leans in to Kelly's face, giving him the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly is taken aback by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie leans back and nods, thinking about Kelly's response. He no longer seems angry.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kelly) Are you one too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you see in that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Living, dying, camaraderie, bravery - the big stuff. Things we don't have anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And do you think it's brave getting trench foot and syphilis, eating another ration of spoiled frank and beans out of a dented can?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, no -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, that wouldn't be much fun, would it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Parts of it were kind of fun though. I got separated from my platoon and lived for two weeks in the forest of the Ardennes living off what I could kill. (pause) I felt very close to the land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kelly sits in the car. Bart pumps gas. They talk through the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly avoids this by getting out of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart returns the pump and screws in the gas cap.

direction.raw_text: Just then he glances towards the gas station and sees EVE, set up in the adjacent abandoned lot. She's got the van parked there with the sliding door open and paintings propped around on display.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly backtracks towards the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve walks over to them. Kelly can't get out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve smiles brightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bart is surprised but recovers his manners quickly, just like he's been taught to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve laughs. Kelly shifts his weight from foot to foot. Eve looks at both of them.

direction.raw_text: Eve watches a car pull into the lot next to the van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly visibly bristles at the thought of his parents entertaining Bart.

direction.raw_text: Eve looks at Kelly. Then she runs back over to the van.

direction.raw_text: Kelly rolls his eyes and gets back in the car.
